subanswer.text: To select a subcommittee with at least one member from each party, we need to count combinations such that no single type dominates completely. One approach uses inclusion-exclusion principle combined with binomial coefficients. Suppose we ignore political affiliations initially and focus purely on counting selections without constraints – we calculate C(14,5). However, some counts include committees with exclusively Republican members \(C(8,5)\) or entirely Democratic ones \(C(6,5)\). By applying Pascal’s rule, our desired quantity equals \(C(14,5)-C(8,5)-C(6,5)\). Therefore, compute \(\binom{14}{5}-\binom{8}{5}-\binom{6}{5}\) to yield the required solution. Hence, employing algebraic manipulation alongside combinatorial principles facilitates solving complex problems involving categorization restrictions efficiently while ensuring accuracy through methodical steps rather than relying solely upon brute computational force.*

0.user_question: A Senate committee has 8 Republicans and 6 Democrats.  In how many ways can we form a subcommittee of 5 members that has at least one member from each party?

ost_step.1: To ensure at least one member from each party, first choose 1 Republican out of the 8 available, which can be done in $\binom{8}{1}=8$ ways.
ost_step.2: Similarly, choose 1 Democrat out of the 6 available, which can be done in $\binom{6}{1}=6$ ways.
ost_step.3: Now, you need to select 3 more members without any restriction since both parties already contribute one member. There are a total of 14 people left ($8-1=7$ Republicans and $6-1=5$ Democrats). Select 3 members from those 14, which can be done in $\binom{14}{3}=364$ ways.

direct_answer.text: To calculate the total number of committees meeting our criteria, multiply together the results above; so it’ll give us $$8\times 6\times 364$$ $$\Rightarrow$$ $$\text{Total Number } =\boxed{17,472}$$

subanswer.text: To select a subcommittee with at least one member from each party, we need to count combinations such that no single type dominates completely. One approach uses inclusion-exclusion principle combined with binomial coefficients. Suppose we ignore political affiliations initially and focus purely on counting selections without constraints – we calculate C(14,5). However, some counts include committees with exclusively Republican members \(C(8,5)\) or entirely Democratic ones \(C(6,5)\). By applying Pascal’s rule, our desired quantity equals \(C(14,5)-C(8,5)-C(6,5)\). Therefore, compute \(\binom{14}{5}-\binom{8}{5}-\binom{6}{5}\) to yield the required solution. Hence, employing algebraic manipulation alongside combinatorial principles facilitates solving complex problems involving categorization restrictions efficiently while ensuring accuracy through methodical steps rather than relying solely upon brute computational force.*
